text: well hunger is the ultimate expression
of poverty and uh that's why there are
still um almost at this stage a billion
people uh suffering from hunger every
day uh that hunger is a combination of
acute malnutrition but that's a small
proportion I mean that's less than 10%
and the really serious problem is
chronic malnutrition about 90% of the
about a billion people are suffering
from chronic malnutrition and it's it's
about people being caught in a desperate
poverty trap uh and they're not at the
moment able to get out of it and I think
the challenge is to see find ways of
both dealing with the immediate problem
and also then helping people out of out
of this poverty trap that they're stuck
in we're very focused on uh on the whole
area of acute malnutrition and we were
very instrumental in developing a
different approach to dealing with that
called Community therapeutic care which
has been adopted last year by the UN as
best practice but we're also dealing
with the whole area of chronic
malnutrition and that's where we're
trying to really break the cycle and
that cycle involves women who pregnant
mothers who are underweight and badly
nourished producing children who are
underweight uh and particularly in the
first two years of life if children are
not properly nourished there's already
stunting comes in there and there's a
huge proportion of the children in the
countries we work in are are affected by
stunting and that means mental and
physical stunting which is IR
irreversible so really that's a key
Focus as well and then at the other end
of the scale as we people we we really
trying to find Pathways out of hunger
for people people uh you know who if we
can improve their livelihoods if we can
get them earning that little bit extra
amount of income then you know they can
grow their own food and they can really
help themselves out of
hunger many of the countries we work in
are are working in very fragile climates
and and particularly areas like the Horn
of Africa Ethiopia Somalia Northern
Kenya uh darur Chad all of these are
very vulnerable places where uh climatic
change and the you know we're we're
facing into more of this are making the
Liv Farmers livelihoods much more
vulnerable uh rains that don't come on
time or that come irregularly and
sometimes come too too too too much rain
um shorter growing Seasons all of these
things so we're looking at you know
different ways of how we can help that
and and some of that will will involve
looking at pastoralist lifestyle life
Lifestyles because many of these areas
in in those uh in those environments are
dealing in in in a past pastoralist
setting and finding solutions to to
their their problems is certainly one of
the things we're doing to deal with
hunger on a long-term and sustainable
way it's it's a lot more than about
either increasing agricultural
production or tackling the immediate
problems of malnutrition it really is
about trying to look at this in a
holistic way obviously Health has a a
very critical role to play in terms of
what some of the methods in the whole
area of child survival so making sure
that mothers are properly uh have have
good health and and small children are
are prop ly both nourished and some of
the
elementary causes I mean when you look
at it um we have close to 10 million
children a year die under the age of
five 10 million children under the age
of five die every year at more than half
of that is caused through a combination
of malnutrition and easily preventable
diseases so if we're to make the biggest
most quickest impact that's where we
have to start and then when you get into
to education if you take a longer term
perspective here one of the critical
things is educating girls and that has
been shown again and again to in in
development terms to give about the
highest return you can get so dealing
with Hunger has to be done in an
integrated way tackling the immediate
food problem but also investing in
education and
health I think uh the remain the issue
of keeping a very clear focus on it at
at both National and international level
I mean and and having policies in place
to deal with it because policy matters
here uh and and and political will to
provide the resources to to uh to fund
policy change but you know we we we have
we had in in Ireland recently something
called we had the Irish hunger task
force which was asking the question you
know what can IR as a country do to
really make an impact on the problem of
world hunger and we came up with two
core priorities the first one was
dealing with tackling nutrition of the
mother and child under two years of age
putting out great deal more emphasis on
that and a great deal more focus on it
and the second one was uh putting a much
greater emphasis on improving the
productivity of smallscale African
farmers and that's a role for for
governments in Africa to to really
change policy on uh but also they need
the support of the International
Community to come in and and and
basically fund improved policy to
achieve to do that
